comments.author: corbinm

comments.text:
Its built partially off of stl files that Robo3D pubilshed, so its a bit cobbled together in Fusion 360. They boost the case 45mm taller.
I can perhaps slice it apart and make a taller version, how much taller did yours end up?
comments.author: corbinm

comments.text: I actually replaced the lead screws in the r1+ with 600mm screws (from robotdigg) and the smooth rods were cut at 26 inches, so I have a fair amount to raise the case. I had done the recent y axis 330mm bed upgrade that on here previously as its quite simple, and that gave me just enough length to print risers of the required length in theory. I needed to add 320mm (If I remember correctly) to get the case tight with the new smooth rods. I used your model and attempted to cut and expand it into the size required with tinkercad, and as you said they are sturdy and work just great :) I would still love to parameterize the model if possible, I know quite a few people are looking into upgrading their lead screws and keeping the look of the case would be high priority. By the way I printed mine vertically the first time, and had a temp fall error from a loose fan in the middle, and when I got it measured out and restarted it, I had a weak joint in mine, so I will be printing a new set that also have some small length adjustments.  Your model was of great help, as I am not particularly good with the modelling yet, and having something to work off of made this a possibility for me where without it there would have been none :)
comments.author: RobMakesStuff

comments.text: @corbinm Ive also done the 330mm extension mod on the bed and would love to extend the Z by whatever I want. Please let us know if you come up with something.

title: Vial holder for stirring multiple vials on lab stirrer/hotplate

description.text: A more elegant solution to magnetic stirring multiple vials on a stirrer/hotplate than bunching them together using elastic bands. It goes without saying that this is for stirring only, heating not recommended. Edit the relevant .SCAD files to choose what to display/print (e.g. main plate, or some of the adaptors only.) These plates and adaptors will fit the vials pictured. No guarantee other sizes vials will be held in place reliably. Feel free to edit adapter sizes in the .SCAD source or design your own (hint: they're hollow cylinders). The main plate will fit the stirrer/hotplates pictured (IKA RCT basic), no guarantee it will fit others. If yours has a circular top, you can edit the required diameter in the .SCAD source code.

title: NESPo - Your own retro NES handheld

description.text:
Turn a NES compatible into your very own portable handheld game system! For obvious reasons, this is a tricky project, and requires additional electronic parts. See this post for a full buildlog with parts:
http://davenunez.wordpress.com/2013/08/16/building-the-nespo/ Print the parts in three colours:
  • Natural PLA for "transparents.stl"
  • A colour you like for parts with "black" in the name
  • Another contrasting colour for the rest of the parts.
    • The .NC parts are GCode to be cut on a laser or CNC router. The SVG file is a template for the face artwork (Inkscape friendly file). Print without supports or rafts.
For a full build log: http://davenunez.wordpress.com/2013/08/16/building-the-nespo/

This contraption was used in photochemistry work to block thermal radiation from high-intensity light sources by passing a slow water current through it.
The .STL files provided will fit standard size microscope slides on both faces (two each for the large one) although the size can be edited in the .SCAD source code.
It goes without saying that the glass slides should be attached securely (and checked for leaks) to the device before placing it over or near electrically powered light sources. High infill values (or solid infill) are probably a good idea to minimize any leaks through pores or gaps in the plastic walls.
The initial design called for single microscope slides to be compressed between two frames on both faces of the device (as seen in the .STL of the small/shallow device). I wasn't able to find a correctly sized O-ring to fit the device so ended up just gluing the glass slides to both sides. If you find a rubber seal of the correct size, a groove for this is part of the design (and its size can be modified slightly in the source code).

title: Xiaomi Yi cam gimbal mount [open brushless gimbal]

description.text:
I decided to model this gimbal mount to make the Open Brushless Gimbal project more famous, because it helped me to make cheaper and lighter gimbal for my quad.
The file "mount_Walkera_X350" have the internal holes for, perhaps, the quadcopter Walkera QR 350/350 pro, anyway You are free to modify and re-upload with the holes for another quad.
As You can see i made a bad-ass version of the original one: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:110731
the mine, has a totally never-viewed-before 6 silicon vibration damper system which can assure more stability and less jello-effect. UPDATE 03.06.2016:
I've uploaded another version in which you can drill the holes for the motor that you prefer. UPDATE 04.07.2016:
Now the mounts for the dampers are more sturdy.

remixed_from.author: jvisser
remixed_from.title: ZMR250 spacer set with camera holder

description.text:
Hi, This is my remix of listed sources. I had spare ZMR250 arms.. so got to do something.
So combined two thing's together and after hours of drawing and sketching it started to get its shape. Used Atom Pdb which has slot for micro Minimosd. Atom Pdb is designed for rev5 Naze32 but can be used with rev6 too, thing is that because usb-connector is on different side on rev6 than rev5, pdb and naze needs to be rotated 90 deg CCW. After rotating pdb esc pads are on wrong corners, you need to wire esc signals to correct pads, not the nearest one. Little Bee esc's are secured with double side tape. Removed sma connector of vtx and soldered pig tail. Rx pins also removed. Nothing special on printing. I printed with ABS, but PLA could do also. Included also cover template which can be used to mark cutting lines and holes in case of CF cover. I recommend CF cover plate as it makes frame stiffer and screws will not go inside prints. Edit: added shims for 4mm arms
added 20deg camera stand for Xiaomi Yi Parts used: Naze32 rev6
Atom Pdb
Micro Minimosd
Pololu 5v 600ma
Aomway 200mw Vtx
Frsky X4r-SB
Little Bee 20A Esc's
1806 2300kv motors
RunCam PZ0420M
ZMR250 bottom plate
ZMR250 3mm arms. (Added shims for 4mm arms :) )

CTC

title: Cap for Lumix G Fisheye 8mm f3.5 lense

description.text:
This is a lense cap designed for the Panasonic Lumix Fisheye lense. Because it is a fisheye, the lense cap holds by friction only. If you lost your cap, like I did, this will probably be very useful. Print the stl file directly of modify the original openscad file if needed. Notice that the scad file has a "tolerance" parameter which you can increase/decrease if the cap is too tight/loose.
I obtained a very good fit printing at 0.2mm resolution on a mendelmax 2.0. I guess printing in black would be ideal for this model...

description.text:
I have used this for testing how to create something from scratch using OpenSCAD (and Inkscape). 
The name tag doubles as a name-stamp in the back.

If you want to make your own you can change the name in the SVG file, then convert font into object, flatten Beziers and export as DXF file. You can fine-tune the sizes of things in the OpenSCAD file.

This is a model of the Saturn V (spoken as "Saturn Five" ) I created on Tinkercad. It is about 20 cm tall, so you may need to scale it down. If you like this, check out my other designs, such as my space shuttle.

description.text: This goals project is to try to encourage teachers, to get 3D Printing into the classroom, and to demonstrate to students how easy it is to design and print an object with a 3D Printer. This project was made in Tinkercad using only 2 shapes.

Program Used To design this I wanted something easy and accessible to anyone, so I used Tinkercad. Step 1 Grab a "roof" block, and extrude it out so it is 5.5 inches long. Step 2 Use Tinkercad's "text" shape generator to create the word teacher, the scale it to fit on the triangle, then group together.

Objectives Students will learn how easy and simple a design can be to produce and print. Audience The audience of this project is for anyone, who wants to learn more about technology, and 3D Printing. Preparation The only thing one will need to do this project is access to an internet connection, and a Thingiverse account. A 3D Printer is optional, but makes it more fun because you can print your design. Steps This project does not have a list of steps, because I believe that the people doing it could have free range, and use their imaginations. Results Students creating this design should have learned how simple 3D modeling and Printing can be.

This helpful tool used to organize classrooms and offices can be a gateway of creativity to students and workers alike. It is used for storage of writing utensils and to make areas a bit more organized.

Pencil/Pen Holder I designed this object using 3D Builder. 3D Builder is the default Microsoft 3D design software. During the creation of this Pencil/pen Holder I used tools like Scale, Group, Rotate, Move, and quite a few others. I took measurements from pencils and pens to determine how large the container should be.

Project: Organization of Space Objectives: The objective of this project is for students to design an effective and easy way to store classroom supplies (i.e. Pencils, pens, glue, scissors, etc.).
Audiences: This project would probably work best in an early middle school environment because students around this age are usually very interested in science and technology.
Preparation: Students should at least know the basics of the program that they are using to design the object as well as have printed at least one thing in the past.
Steps:
  • Students should be put into groups of two or three so they can brainstorm ideas of what they could print that would make their classroom more organized
  • Students should have a good amount of time (at least a week) to brainstorm, design, and print their idea.
  • Apply the ideas of the students and place their final projects around the classroom (this will make it so more students will come in contact with these objects).
  • A student should have at least designed something creative and something that can at least hold a glue stick. Students should be graded more on how they can work in a team rather than their final project (this is more so up to the teacher than it is up to me).

title: Keyboard Stand for Logitech K810 Bluetooth Keyboard

description.text: I have the Logitech K810 Bluetooth keyboard and my only complaint about it is that it lays flat on the desk.  I like keyboards that are raised on an angle.  So I created two slip on stands for the keyboard that inclines it.   Because this keyboard is portable I wanted something that was easy to use and transport.

Printer:

XYZPrinting Da Vinci Duo

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

10%

Notes: I orientated it on its side so you wouldn't need supports. I printed mine at .3 as this is more a utility type object and not a show piece and it prints faster. I also removed some material from the middle of the supports to speed up printing and to use less filament.

I decided the incline I wanted and then went to Tinkercad and rotated a block to that angle.  Then added additional blocks for the overhangs that hold the keyboard in place.  I then used the subtract tool to remove excess and added some curves.  
I scaled it based off the measurements of my keyboard.  I then printed it and refined the sizing thru two more pro-types before I got the fit I wanted.

author: dehart007

description.text: These are velcro mounts for the GoPro Hero video camera. They were designed to easily attach to RC plane fuselages and wings. I have since used them to attach the camera to my leg and helmet. They work remarkably well. I used these mounts to film this video of my RC glider: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3jVroP8jzSQ Update: After numerous flights, and other unplanned uses, the mounts are holding up well. Slope Combat: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hyWu5y56QWc

Print solid.  Clean out overhangs. (I've had the best luck printing it out flat, and it has been plenty strong).
Use less than 20mm wide velcro(double sided) strip (I got mine from Micheal's arts and crafts store) to attach to RC plane, leg, helmet, etc...
If the surface is easily damageable (like a plane's wing), add some soft foam to the backside of the mount.
Don't forget to add a safety line to your camera...just in case the camera comes UN-attatched somehow.

remixed_from.author: PrintableScience
remixed_from.title: Mount Rushmore from Internet Images & Free Software

description.text:
This is a stylized version of Mt. Rushmore using busts of those four presidents that clearly don't look the same as the real deal, but we like it!
I got the Teddy Roosevelt from the Scan the World archive at the following address:
https://www.myminifactory.com/object/bust-of-theodore-roosevelt-at-the-american-museum-of-natural-history-2011 With its use, the entire thing can be published under the license I want, which using other models on Thingiverse wouldn't allow.
The lens frames are added to Roosevelt and know in advance that they're too thin to print well, which turns out great for one of the few times in 3D printing! It's on purpose. Only fragments of them slice and print, so the print winds up looking much like the real Mt. Rushmore in that respect. Go with it! :D
I did sculpt in some eyes and put a mouth on Jefferson, as well as repairing the top of his head, to try to bring him up to speed and get him closer in sculpting to the other models he'd be next to. I mottled his skin a bit, too.
No supports needed- my favorite kind of print!
I have one modeled up with some trees on it, but I plan to look at photographs of the actual place now and move them where they belong! Will be adding that file soon.

title: Ultimaker 2 Extended Aluminum Extrusion Back Cover

description.text:
I made a UM2 Aluminum Extrusion by jasonatepaint but decided to make it an UM2 Extended Version. I wanted a back cover for the print bed to indicate Extended so I made one from the github version of the back panel github version of the back panel NOTE:
2 version uploaded
  • Long (normal version) this is the same height as the normal back cover and goes all the way up to the top of the Z bearings
  • Short, about 13.1mm shorter as some guys complaining the cover hitting the timing belt.
    • I am using the long version BOM:
    You need the same M3 x 15 screw and nut to lock it on the bed. The M2 x 16 can be used as well as the UM2 Instruction: You need to flip when slicing as it seems to be upside down when I imported it. No need for support and low infill will do. Careful on first layer the word "Extended" may not stick well if too fast print speed.

comments.text: Hi. Can you point me in the direction as to what print carriage you are using. I would like to use direct drive as opposed to Bowden setup.
comments.author: Seg2016

comments.text: During this project I have used jasonatepaint PG35L direct drive. Now, in comparison i moved to Bondtech bowden but they are no better on the PG35L direct drive. The only difference is that you can run very slightly faster print speed with bondtech bowden. There are other directdrive mods like the E3d Titan but I havent tried them myself.

author: steyrc

description.text: http://youtu.be/spcXJ6ALmOE Now considered finished unless I fix the offline cut in layer 3, noting there is no gap in model, its just annoying... Will add images of the final prints when finished. Update 6 Added hollow layer 4 back, with lid. Lids for top front and back face each other, so you can have a complete hollow brain case. Update 5. Beginning to look good with simple RGB leds, as I print piece by piece. Added Hollow Layer 4 Front stl as the translucent prints with lights inside look too good! Update 4. Got a good print of layer 2 front, by laying it on its back, so lips facing up. Support internally was much less than I expected, and it came out really well, all other orientations had faults in the gcode, or unprintable implications, such as single width skirt of support that just fails eventually. Shame I didnt cut the back parrallel, but it is managable to align close to the bed. Update 3. Finding printing the hollow layer 2 front difficult, trying one final orientation. Though frustrating I did not cut the back parrallel to the Y in the first place so that complicates things. Also added a hollow layer 3 front and lid, which should print far easier. Update 2. Added a hollow Chin piece, layer2Font and lid, because it seemed like the right thing to do! Bear in mind this is a work in progress, I have not tried to print it yet, so you may want to wait until I publish a success image or otherwise... Update 1. Warning, layer2front_fixed,stl had an unexpected internal void, the inside of the mouth, I have fixed this while playing with the model, and uploaded a new layer2front_fixed.stl

This is a full size head model, to ensure I scale the next Halo helmet correctly to my head size. This is NOT my head, it is a generic model from http://grabcad.com/library/head-model I have sized it as close to my own head as I can, and will use that as a template to rescale the halo helmet to. I am also printing it, as it will be curious to have around, and is a good base for modular upgrades... I will add pictures as I print.

Use 1/8th by 3/4 inch slotted tension pins for assembly.  
Print chin model, with the mouth facing up, I support issues implied in any other orientation, that proved to be unprintable.  
This gives a very interesting hex pattern from the in fill when lit from inside. Better than the eyes section which I printed in normal orientation and may of been more atheistic if also printed facing up.  
Print the "lids" in opaque plastic to prevent light bleed between layers.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/ghP0t7ZgO3G

The Teenage Engineering Pocket Operator is a pretty cool device. And in my opinion does not lack in anything, except for some type of button lock. Made this shell to prevent the PO to start playing unintentionally in my pocket, which happens quite often. Since most of the sound from the speaker is directed towards the back of the unit, I used the battery cover to channel the sound towards the user instead. I used Excefil PLA for the parts except for the buttons that are printed with Ninja Flex. The button plate were printed with transparent PLA to make LED´s shines through. For me the Button_09 was a perfect fit, but I added some alternatives for you to try. I found that printing a batch of buttons rather then printing one by one, gave me better results due to the heat distribution. You will need to drill out the screw holes for the proper diameter of the screws. I used 4x 2.5mm screws (+nuts) to hold it together. Added some extra material around the audio jacks to prevent warping, that needs to be cut away. Also had to do some after treatment with a file, exacto knife and some sandpaper to get the perfect fit around the unit. **Update 20016-02-16 Redesigned the battery cover to make the after treatment easier.
Had some issues getting the buttons to work with PLA (non flex material). So I redesigned the "Front_shell", "Lid" and added some new buttons for them. These versions have "PLA" as a prefix in the file names. If you have trouble with the buttons, try these.

title: Get girls into STEM with Lego Hair #MakerEdChallenge

description.text:
There's a running gag that the biggest obstacle to girls growing up to be engineers is representation: you'll have 99 lego construction guys to one lego businesswoman. But a lego construction guy is just a lego construction woman without hair...
[cover picture is a mock-up. Sorry, I can't print anything yet]

I used freeCAD, an as-advertised free CAD program - a particularly strong choice for spotty internet access, with an excellent Undo history. Measure the model. In my case there were plenty of dimensions available online, and I just had to convert from metric. I started with the head diameter, added an arbitrary thickness, and created a construction circle - centered on the origin - with half that for the radius. Then I added an octagon around that, also centered on the origin, and picked any 3 sides to be tangent to the first circle. Then I set one side to be strictly vertical (or horizontal) so it won't spin, and we have our fully constrained base. Close the sketch and use the Pad button to bring it into the third dimension; from my measurements, I decided to pad it 0.45" Then select the top of the head and create another octagon around a circle, this time with radius 0.1 Pad that up a good 80 thou (0.08"); now flip the model over and add a sketch to the bottom, a simple circle of radius 0.202 Pocket that out of our solid with a depth of 0.375; now a minifig head could fit inside, mostly Now put another circle in the new pocket, radius 0.096". A hexagon might grab and release better, or some sort of flexible C shape, but I don't have a 3D printer, so I haven't tested the theory. Pocket this another 80 thou; now there's a place for the stud on top of the minifig's head to grab onto Okay, now we have a really basic Lego helmet. You can stop here if you want, maybe paint a funny mask on it-I'm going to keep going.
Next we'll put a stud on top - so this helmet can itself wear a construction helmet, or police hat, etc. Add a circle, radius 0.096 again. Can't remember why I changed the color here Pad it up 80 thou That's pretty good. Let's open it up a little so we can see the Lego face. Select the front face of the original hexagon and create another sketch.
I went with a tombstone shape, but you can do whatever you like as long as it's fully constrained. Use X to pull in eXternal geometries (like the edges of this face), so you can anchor and center your new sketch - I used diagonal construction lines and constrained them to be equal, this is a handy trick that comes up a lot. When you're happy with the shape, close the sketch and punch it in. I figure about halfway into the helmet is safe - you probably don't want to drill all the way through the back, so about 0.2? Don't worry about the sides, we're about to fix those. Now go to either side and sketch a profile. I'm not entirely happy with the sideburns on girl hair, but they define the ears, and that's important. Now we punch, but instead of a dimension, let's punch Through All Now it's looking more like hat hair; again, we could stop right here and print it, but I'm going to keep going. Let's go to the back and add a ponytail. New sketch, a centered circle of radius 0.064" (this is a reoccurring measurement - the base of a plume or a flame, roughly the size of a stud). Pad it a few thou, I think I went 40 Now let's pocket another centered circle, radius 0.032 (another reoccurring measurement, the stem of plumes - this hair could have any number of ponytails: fire, feathers, flags, etc) I forget the depth on this, 60 thou maybe Now for the heck of it, let's chamfer the edge, give it a ponytail band look. And let's not forget the ponytail - that's a similar sketch, padded arbitrarily, then take the edge and sketch a circle on that, pad it, another circle on that, pad that, and you're done. From here out it's all artistry - not freeCAD's strong suit, but with this strong geometric base you can export into a more feature-rich artistic program, like Blender (at which I am presently horrible).

description.header: Project - Make your own Lego Hair
description.text:
Objectives Students will learn how to make a geometrically constrained base compatible with Lego Minifigs; alternately, provide the above files to art students and those students will learn how to build on an existing model without warping the original internal geometries. Audiences Depending on the version of this project, it could either be art students who understand the Blender basics or math students who understand the FreeCad basics. (I could be sneaky and split this into two entries, but who has that kind of time) Preparation Students will need computers onto which FreeCAD either has already been installed; unless this is the art project, in which case they'll need Blender, which is also free. Steps! In the version where you're following How I Designed This, just follow how I designed mine. I pulled it off in a couple hours without a guide, so it can't be too hard.
In the version where art students are making something pretty out of something functional:
  • Download the file smoothlegohelm.stl from this page and (optional) legoponytail.stl
  • Import it into your 3D Art Program
  • Draw hair on the outsides of the helm, without going above the top line or altering the insides. You may remove the ponytail if you like.
  • Print your product and see how it looks. If I designed it properly and the default fits a standard minifig, the artistic helmets ought also to fit a standard minifig; and the ponytails ought to be interchangable.
    • Results: For the geometric version, assessment should be based on functionality - if it works, good job.
    For the artistic version: effort, vision, and preserved function are all key.

author: GenCode

title: CTC Dual Printer Filament/tube guide - No Screws or Cutting!

description.text:
Filament guide that uses the holes in the back of the CTC dual printer (i think for cable ties?). Using this with some 4mm tubing.
Print 2 clips and the Mount to attach securely to the printer (put the top clip in from the bottom to avoid aggravation!)
Print 2 of the pole pieces, these are segmented to achieve the height needed so the tubing isnt under much tension.
print the pole end and slot in to the pole piece (into the pole piece, into the mount), then feed your tube through. 
I havent come up with a good way to allow the tube to be pulled out easily, since squeezing it through a smaller cut distorts the tube. This isnt very field tested either but seems okay so far.

author: jeffers727

title: Sliders/Carriage for Delta Kossel 2020 Original Wheels and Openbuilds Part Store V Wheels

description.text: Sliders for 2020 extrusion and Openbuilds Part Store Solid V Wheel kit. This is an adaptation of many designs for sliders that I have seen. This is a two part slider with the front (inside) piece capable of mounting any carriage with 20 mm x 20mm screw spacing for 3mm screws. There is a screw to adjust the wheel tension on the extrusion. The slider is sized for the regular 2020 extrusion that comes with the Kossel 2020 printer kit from Folgertech. I don't know how this would work with the V-slot extrusion. I am using the carriage design that came with the kit except that I have added a hole for an adjustment screw on the top to make end stop settings more precise. Based on requests, I have modified the design to work with the Mini V Wheel. I have not tested this as I do not have the mini V wheels. I adjusted the bolt axle spacing based on the published diameters of the two types of wheels. You will have to provide your own spacers or modify the sketchup files. Please leave me a comment if you try the mini v wheel sliders and they work or don't work.. Update: Added .stl and .skp files for carriage with extended belt attachment studs. This allows the belts to be aligned with the pulleys. Update: Added .stl and .skp files for sliders that work with the original nylon wheels that come with the kit. Requires 8 mm spacers. See my Delta 3D printer modification for manual bed leveling and heated glass printing here

Printer:

Kossel 2020 Delta

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

20%

Notes: There are several versions included for download. Each slider requires a front (inside) and a back (outside). The components can be printed with integral 10mm spacers or they can be printed without spacers and used with separate spacers of the desired depth. There are also two versions of the back (outside). A full version has the same outside dimensions as the front (inside) while the cutaway version has the extraneous material removed for weight savings. If using the original nylon wheels, use the 8mm spacers.

Requirements Each slider requires three 5mm x 40mm hex head bolts.
The Solid V wheels come with a 5mm nylock nuts.
http://openbuildspartstore.com/solid-v-wheel-kit/
Any carriage with 20x20 spacing can be used and is attached with 3mm screws and 3mm nylock nuts.
The tension adjustment screws are 3mm x 25mm.

Motivation I think the stock sliders on the Kossel 2020 printer are a weakness in the design. The Openbuild Parts Store Solid V wheels are far superior to the wheels that come with the kit. I also wanted to add support on the back (outside) of the extrusions to give the wheels a more stable axle shaft. The captive hex head bolts are easier to assemble than the flathead philips screws that come with the kit.

description.text:
A simple and strong quick release for you to quickly mount and dismount your camera, or whatever, on anything you want. I am using this to mount my DSLR on a time lapse panning rig.   
Another good use is to place this on a tripod that doesn't have a quick release.

Press in the two nuts, screw down the handle with the flat head bolt. 
Stick the pan head bolt in the bottom of the the quick release plate and screw it to your device. 
The more you turn the handle the tighter it gets.
Moving the handle back and forth causes the bolt to loosen up so it is a good idea to use some thread lock or something to hold the bolt in place. I might modify the part to accept a nylock nut, perhaps a nylock jam nut may already fit.

description.text: This word pen has the ball-point inner printed in place, so it ends up embedded inside the pen body. This provides a crisp, sealed-in finish. This pen body is rounded making it more comfortable to write with. The output file includes a fitted cap and helper tabs to prevent the print from lifting off the build-plate during printing. The pen length scales according to the text length which is automatically centred. The dimensions of the ball-point inner should be checked before customising - see instructions.

I have been successfully printing this pen with ReplicatorG and Sailfish firmware by taking advantage of the Sailfish [email protected] function. Successful printing requires precise measurement of your filament diameter to ensure the cap and ball-point inner fit snugly. I created a duplicate profile and edited the start.gcode to add M322 Z4.5 to the bottom of the file. This tells the sailfish firmware to pause at 4.5mm. You can obviously pause the printer manually, or set the zpos position using the printer control interface, but if you plan to print a lot of pens, creating a custom profile in ReplicatorG is the way to go. I have included a sample ReplicatorG/Sailfish profile for the Replicator 2 that includes this modification and fine tuned settings for printing these pens. The ball point cartridges I am using are pretty standard. They were just a cheap packet of 20 generic pens I purchased at my local Office Works. However you will need to get out your digital callipers and measure them precisely and adjust the settings if they do not match. The tip_diameter on my pen inner was 2.14, which I rounded up 2.4. The inner_diameter of my pen inner was 2.9, which I rounded up to 3.4. The inner_diameter value can have looser tolerance than the tip_diameter to make insertion of the inner easier. The inner length is measured from just below the ball-point tip to the end of the inner.

title: Fume Exhaust Adapters for Garden Hose

description.text:
I didn't want to cut into the printer to exhaust the fumes, so I figured that since the pipes that the filament spools are on are hollow and threaded, I'd use them.
Firstly, I designed a cap to cut off airflow through the right pipe since I'm not using it. Next, I made an adapter that would allow me to use a garden hose to connect to the outside threads of the other pipe and keep the filament spool in place.
Then I created another adapter to hold my fan (1.59") in place over the exhaust pipe.
Of course all of this exhaust needs a place to vent out... so I came up with a design that fits through a .5" board and is screwed into place. A standard garden hose can then be attached. To keep rain from entering the hose, an exhaust hood was made. I put a grill into the exhaust hood to help prevent bugs and whatever from crawling inside (also provides support for the printing). I also placed a piece of screen material between the sections for a good measure of protection.
I had to design a 90 degree adapter for my hose since the wall is too close to the back of my printer and would kink the hose. I made my own supports for the adapters and they can be simply removed with a twist of some pliers.

ReplicatorG
Skienforge (50)
Slicing Profile: Replicator 2 Slicing Defaults
(Infill_PerimeterOverlap(ratio): 0.3)

Small sanding plane I designed for 1" (25mm) sandpaper. Overall size is 150mm long by 25mm wide by 50mm tall. You will need the following hardware (or similar) (2) 3mm x 10mm screws
(2) 3mm washers
(2) 3mm heat set nut inserts (used in building some 3D printers).
Sandpaper 25mm wide by 23.5mm long. I suggest printing with 6 top, bottom & perimeters (you want it to be strong) and 40% infill with .20mm layer height. Print 2 of the Sanding Block Pins and 1 sanding block. Assemble as shown in the photos. Insert sandpaper strip into 1 end (into the circular cutout) and tighten down the screw. Next wrap the sandpaper around the bottom and insert into other side. Make sure to hold the paper stretched as tight as you can while screwing down the second screw. Enjoy!

description.header: For a Samsung Galaxy S4 in Rubber Jacket
description.text:
ALTERNATIVE VERSIONS WITH LOWER GRIP & RABBIT EARS:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1327029 This is a quick one I threw together to get printed so I could use my Phone as a Sat Nav whilst here in America. I was fortunate enough that I had my Engineering Knowledge and access to a Makerbot 2. The MB2 is pretty good, and this is the first time I've printed in PLA. It looks great. OK, so I do have data, but since I've got a (former) flagship Android Phone I use an app called Navigator free. It uses Offline Maps AND ROUTING - courtesy of Open Street Map. Whilst the roaming data costs me nothing, I find it reassuring that if I were to lose my signal, I can still find where I'm goin g. So the VW hire car I'm in has this dumb central display screen. Between the Airport and the Hotel I just rested my phone in front of it. That worked well. However one time I turned Right, Phone slid off to the right, hit the Radio "Vol Up" and turned the radio up to 11... I've modelled this to fit a Samsung Galaxy S4 with a rubberised case on it. It clips bently on the side (unfortunately exactly where the Vol and On buttons are). It then lodges between the two round dial cowellling, and whilst the phone CAN move, it's unlikely to slide off, fall on the floor and put Spinal Tap on too loud. "Stonehenge, where the demons dwell
Where the banshees live and they do live well......" Peace out, EUR ING Andy Southern,
aka BathRobotics.

title: Grinder Funnel
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a funnel device for attaching to a multi-stage hand grinder. It allows you to easily regulate, and control the direction of flow of material out of the grinder. This particular design was made with the Sharpstone 2.2" herb grinder in mind: http://www.sharpstonegrinders.com/sharpstone-clear-top-4-piece-grinder-2-2-silver/ I have had some success scaling it to fit grinders of slightly different brand/size. Let me know if you are able to make it work for other grinders.

If you have the same size grinder as me then you don't need any scaling and should be able to print directly and start with step 1. If it is a different size scale it using 53.3mm as the base size of mine.
  • Print out the piece. I like the ABS ones I've printed more but the PLA ones work fine too.
  • I print mine with a raft, so the next step is to remove the raft. I use a Dremel.
  • Depending on how good your printer is at doing overhangs/bridges, the thread ring may be a little wonky. If it is just take a Dremel or other rotary sanding device to it to even things out.
  • Test for fit on your grinder and make any necessary changes.
  • Enjoy improved control on your hand grinder.

description.text:
This need for speed rocket was designed the day after I first tried to fly the "Modular Rocket" design [ http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8754 ] from this site; video: [ http://youtu.be/4qqQSMpU9F8 ]. Plus, I wanted to take advantage of the height of my Rostock Max build area to make a ridiculously tall rocket. In it I fit the largest engine you can get at a regular hobby shop in the slimmest possible package. WARNING: This design has not been tested. Fly at your own risk. See the list of possible failures below. Specs Length: 1.3 meters
Diameter: 26mm OD, 25mm ID
Width: 57mm
Engine: 24mm x 93mm
Weight: ## This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/8Yjxvd6FzVC

Designed to be printed on a Rostock Max printer (around 13.5" tall segments.) Fits an Estes E class engine, but you could make a spacer to fit D. You will need to pack the nose cone with clay so it is at least as heavy as the full engine. The center of pressure on this is fairly far forward, so without weight in the nose cone it will be unstable. I haven't flown this yet, so use at your own risk. Things That Could Go Wrong

  • the initial pulse could cause the weight of the nosecone to compress and break the fragile tube, which would shatter and not just bend, and the fincan would fly uncontrolled around and/or away from the launch pad at head level. HIGH RISK OF INJURY

  • the dynamic pressure and vibration during flight could cause it to break apart, allowing the fincan to fly uncontroled and the nose to come down areodynamicly. Watch for falling debris. MODERATE RISK OF INJURY.

  • i have no idea if the tube can handle the pressure of the ejection charge. It could rupture. However, since this would happen at apogee, debris would have to fall further and probably wouldn't be areodynamic. LOW RISK OF INJURY
    • ...and probably more situations I can't predict. And then... it might fly great.

comments.text: Try testing this rocket in Openrocket, a free rocket simulator.
comments.author: decross

comments.text: My main worry is that the dynamic stresses on the body might cause it to break mid-flight causing it to fly out of control. I'm fairly certain the configuration is stable.
comments.author: decross

title: OmniDerby Girl (18mm scale)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: In the massive hub-cities that serve as transition points between the Known Worlds, no sport is more popular than OmniDerby. Throughout the Prime-Time League, no team is as feared as the Nexus City Trauma Queens. This character was modeled for our sci-fantasy tabletop RPG, Wayfarer: Things Beyond Wonder and for Wayfarer Tactics. If you want to print a 28mm scale version, just scale it up by 166.6%. Get a start on your 3D-printed fantasy army! We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested to help fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...) Enjoy!
